headline.main: Rebel-Style Advances, Incoming Bills and Fading Anthrax Fears

lead_paragraph: It was a crystalline blue day in New York -- remarkably like Sept. 11 -- ideal for Veterans Day and for taking stock after two months of living with terror. Much of the news was like the parade, solemn but upbeat. Major progress in the war in Afghanistan was reported. There were no new anthrax cases. And at the rubble of the World Trade Center, President Bush and other dignitaries attended a memorial service for all nations that lost citizens in the terrorist attack. A BREAKOUT -- After years holed up in northeast Afghanistan, Northern Alliance forces backed by American bombing and advisers appeared to be making surprising progress, with alliance leaders saying they had captured the town of Taliqan without firing a shot and had made new gains across the north.
abstract: Overview of war in Afghanistan and homeland security; Pres Bush attends memorial at World Trade Center site two months after terror attack; Northern Alliance troops appear to be making progress as they advance toward Kabul, Afghan capital; cost of war is estimated at $1 billion per month; no new anthrax cases are reported but death of Kathy Nguyen is still shrouded in mystery (M)
